title-group.article-title: High nutritional risk is associated with worse health-related quality of life in patients with heart failure beyond sodium intake

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: The most desirable outcome in heart failure (HF) management is to improve health-related quality of life (HRQoL) as a patient-centred health outcome. Nutrition is assumed to be important in HF management, whereas there is little evidence that nutritional risk affects HRQoL, except for sodium.

sec.title: Purpose:
sec.p: We aimed to determine whether nutritional risk is associated with worse HRQoL after controlling for daily sodium intake. Methods: A total of 134 consecutive patients with HF [age 63±11 years, 35% female, 45% New York Heart Association (NYHA) class III/IV, ejection fraction (EF) 33±13%] completed the Nutrition Screening Initiative (NSI) to assess nutritional risk and a 24-h urine sodium excretion assessment to estimate daily sodium intake at baseline. The Minnesota Living with HF Questionnaire was used to evaluate HRQoL at baseline and 6 months later. Hierarchical linear regressions were used to determine whether nutritional risk predicted HRQoL at baseline and 6 months later.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Seventy-eight (58.2%) patients had high nutritional risk as indicated by a total NSI score ≥6. Increased nutritional risk was independently associated with worse HRQoL at baseline and 6 months later (β=0.33, p<0.001; β=0.35, p<0.001, respectively), after controlling for age, gender, aetiology, body mass index, NYHA class, EF, total comorbidity score, prescribed medications, and daily sodium intake.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: These findings show that higher nutritional risk beyond sodium intake affects worse HRQoL in patients with HF. Further work is required to provide specific dietary guidelines to improve health outcomes for patients with HF.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The ultimate goal of heart failure (HF) management is to improve health-related quality of life (HRQoL) of patients with HF. HRQoL reflects patients’ subjective perceptions about the multi-dimensional impact of their clinical condition and treatment on their daily lives including physical functioning and symptoms, emotional distress, and social activities.1–3 Poor HRQoL has been shown to predict cardiac mortality or morbidity in HF patients.4,5 In addition, HRQoL plays a more important role in determining health status than does objective physical status.6,7 Most patients express a preference for better HRQoL compared to a longer life.8,9 However, the role of HRQoL as a health outcome has received substantially less attention.

Nutrition is thought to be an important component of HF management. Indeed, approximately half of patients with HF suffer from malnutrition as seen in progressive weight loss, which is associated with higher rates of cardiac death.10,11 Additionally, worsening HF symptoms, such as increased activity intolerance may, be more aggravated by poor nutrition.12 Loss of appetite, age-related changes in taste and smell, dietary sodium and caloric restriction, social isolation, and use of diuretics were identified to affect inadequate food intake, resulting in poor nutritional status.12–16 Despite raising concerns about the poor nutritional status of HF patients, dietary recommendation in HF management has focused predominantly on a sodium-restricted diet.

Previous researchers reported the impact of a sodium-restricted diet on health outcomes including HRQoL,17,18 while there has been little examination of the link between whole nutritional risk and HRQoL, except for sodium intake. Furthermore, nutrition-related research in patients with HF has been relatively limited and is insufficient to provide specific recommendations in clinical practice.16,19 A few prior investigators20,21 have reported that single or complex nutritional supplements were helpful in improving HRQoL through randomized controlled trials. However, these interventions were carried out for only a small number of HF patients. In addition, it has been known that a sodium-restricted diet is unpalatable and subsequently related to decreased appetite, leading to higher risk for poor nutritional intake.14,19,22 However, dietary sodium intake was not controlled for in most studies examining the effects of nutrient supplementation on HRQoL.20,21 Also, HRQoL of patients with HF can be improved or impaired over time within 6 months without any intervention.20,23–25 Given the potential for change in HRQoL of patients with HF, it is essential to determine the impact of nutritional risk on HRQoL prospectively.

To address these gaps in knowledge, we aimed to: (1) compare nutritional risk-based differences in sample characteristics, and (2) prospectively determine whether nutritional risk is associated with worse HRQoL among community-dwelling patients with HF after controlling for daily sodium intake.

sec.title: Design and setting
sec.p: A prospective, descriptive study design was used to determine the impact of nutritional risk on HRQoL beyond daily sodium intake among community-dwelling patients with HF. Patients were recruited from outpatient HF clinics in two regional tertiary medical centres located in Seoul, South Korea.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: Eligibility criteria for this study included: having a cardiologist-confirmed diagnosis of chronic HF for at least 2 years; being on a stable medication regimen including beta-blockers, diuretics, or angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors for at least 6 months; having impaired left ventricular systolic function with left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of less than 50%; and being able to read, write, and speak Korean.

Participants were excluded from this study if they had a contraindication to low sodium diet; an acute myocardial infarction 6 months before enrolment, any hospitalizations or emergency room visits in the 3 months prior to this study, any obvious cognitive impairment, defined as a diagnosis of cerebrovascular accident or dementia, a history of terminal illness such as cancer, severe hyperthyroidism, or hepatic or renal failure, or were undergoing cardiac transplant evaluation.

The required sample size for this study was calculated using a power analysis suggested by Erdfelder and colleagues.26 Considering a medium effect size (f2=0.15), α of 0.05, 80% power (1–β), and a total of 12 independent variables, a sample size of at least 127 patients was required to obtain the G* power.27

A total of 164 patients were eligible for this study. Ten patients declined to participate and five patients withdrew. Nine patients did not complete the 24-h urine collection and six patients were lost to follow up. Thus, data from 134 patients were included in this study.

sec.title: Nutritional risk
sec.p: Nutritional risk was evaluated by using the Nutrition Screening Initiative (NSI) checklist.28 This checklist was developed through a collaboration of the American Dietetic Association, the American Academy of Family Physicians, and the National Council on the Aging to screen community-dwelling older adults.28 It is a frequently used instrument designed to identify individuals whose diets are relatively low in nutrient intake compared to the recommended dietary allowance standards.28 The checklist consists of ten yes/no questions, each of which has a weight of 1 to 4. Cumulative scores can range from 0 to 21; higher scores indicate greater nutritional risk. The NSI checklist has been demonstrated to be valid for assessing nutritional risk in elderly people.29,30 The recommended cut-offs are as follows: a total NSI score of 6 or higher indicates high nutritional risk, a total NSI score of 3–5 indicates moderate nutritional risk, and a total NSI score of 0–2 indicates good nutritional status. Prior investigators reported the reliabilities of the NSI checklist with Cronbach’s α ranging from 0.68 to 0.75 among Korean elderly.31,32 In this study, the internal consistency of the NSI was demonstrated by a Cronbach’s α of 0.71.

sec.title: Dietary sodium intake
sec.p: Dietary sodium intake per day was determined by measuring a 24-h urinary sodium excretion,33 which is considered to be an objective measure of daily sodium intake.34 At least 85% of dietary sodium intake is excreted in urine.35,36 A 24-h urinary sodium excretion has been correlated with dietary sodium intake as estimated by a food intake37 and dietary records review.38,39 Urine sodium excretion in millimoles was converted to milligrams (mg=mmol×22.99). If patients had a 24-h urine volume of less than 500 ml or excretion of creatinine <10mg/kg/day, those cases were considered incomplete,40 and were excluded from the data analysis.

sec.title: Health-related quality of life (HRQoL)
sec.p: The Minnesota Living with Heart Failure Questionnaire (LHFQ)3 was used to assess HRQoL at baseline and 6 months later. This instrument was developed specially to measure HF patients’ perception of how much their illness and its treatment affects perceived quality of life.3 This instrument is the most commonly used disease-specific measure in HF research and clinical practice. The LHFQ consists of 21 items rated on a scale from 0 (no effect) to 5 (very much). Item ratings are summated for a total score that can range from 0 to 105. Higher scores reflect worse HRQoL. The LHFQ contains two subscales: physical and emotional. The physical subscale consists of eight items (difficulties in daily activities, resting, sleeping, and impact of HF symptoms) and the emotional subscale consists of five items (emotional distress and cognitive problems). The other eight items are used only in the total score (difficulties in social activities, sexual activity, eating, hospitalization, medical costs, and side effects from medications). Several investigators have examined the psychometric properties of the LHFQ in patients with HF and found strong reliabilities of the total, physical, and emotional scales with Cronbach’s α ranging from 0.88 to 0.93.3,23,41,42 In this study, the internal consistency of the total, physical, and emotional scales was demonstrated by a Cronbach’s α of 0.92, 0.91, and 0.90, respectively.

sec.title: Other risk factors
sec.p: Other risk factors including age, gender, presence of spouse, body mass index (BMI), New York Heart Association (NYHA) class, aetiology of HF, LVEF, comorbidity level as measured by the Charlson’s comorbidity index,43 and prescribed medications were collected through patient interviews and review of medical records. The Charlson’s comorbidity index43 was designed to classify comorbid conditions that might change the risk for mortality.

sec.title: Data collection
sec.p: The research proposal and protocol were approved by the Institutional Review Board at each enrolment site prior to data collection. After potential subjects meeting the inclusion criteria were identified by the primary investigator, a trained research assistant contacted eligible patients to inquire about willingness to have the primary investigator contact them by telephone to explain the purposes and procedures for the study. Once verbal consent was obtained from eligible patients, the primary investigator called to make an appointment for a visit to an outpatient clinic. Written informed consent was subsequently obtained from patients in an outpatient clinic, prior to data collection.

A trained research assistant provided patients with a urine collection container and a sheet to record the time and volume of each urination, and provided instructions on the procedures for urine collection. Patients collected all of their urine over a specified 24-h period. After completion of the 24-h urine collection, patients brought their urine containers to outpatient HF clinics and then completed a series of questionnaires. A trained research assistant reviewed the questionnaires and the 24-h urine collection sheets to ensure completeness. If patients forgot to save urine or lost any amount of urine, those cases were considered incomplete and were not included in the final analysis. At 6 months after baseline assessment, patients were provided the LHFQ to assess HRQoL in an outpatient clinic.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: SPSS for Windows 18.0 was used for data analysis in this study. Descriptive statistics were used to describe the patient characteristics. The independent t-test and chi-squared tests were used to compare differences in sample characteristics between patients with higher nutritional intake and those with lower nutritional intake. Hierarchical multiple linear regression was used to determine whether nutritional risk was independently associated with worse HRQoL at baseline and 6 months later after controlling for other risk factors and daily sodium intake. Other risk factors including age, gender, presence of spouse, BMI, HF aetiology, LVEF, comorbidity level, and prescribed medications were found to be related to impaired HRQoL in HF patients in previous studies.44–48

A total LHFQ score at baseline and 6 months later were almost normally distributed. Skewness of a total LHFQ score at baseline and 6 months later were 0.30 and 0.31, respectively, while kurtoses of a total LHFQ score at baseline and 6 months later were −0.70 and −0.59. To control for possible multicollinearity issues, a collinearity analysis including tolerance value, variance inflation factor (VIF) and condition index was performed before conducting the multiple linear regression. The multicollinearity assumption was not violated in this study with the Durbin Watson statistic of 1.896, the tolerance value of 0.756–0.946 (>0.5) and VIF of 1.057–1.323 (close to 1–2). Adjusted R2 was calculated to explain how well nutritional risk predicted HRQoL at baseline and 6 months later in HF patients after controlling for other risk factors and daily sodium intake. The p-value of less than 0.05 was considered statistically significant.

sec.title: Sample characteristics
sec.p: Sample characteristics are shown in Table 1. The patients were primarily male with an age range of 45–97 years. About 70% of the patients were of normal weight or overweight in accordance with the obesity cut-off points for East Asians established by the World Health Organization.49 The majority of patients were in NYHA functional class II or III. Seventy percent of patients had hypertension and one-third had diabetes mellitus as comorbidities. Over the half of the patients lived with a spouse. Most patients were taking prescribed beta-blockers, diuretics, and ACE inhibitors. Fifty-four percent of patients had a 24-h urinary sodium excretion that indicated a daily sodium intake of greater than 3 g. Seventy-eight patients (58.2%) had high nutritional risk as indicated by a total NSI score equal to or greater than 6. Overall, participants had lower scores in HRQoL at baseline with a range of 0–96.

sec.title: Nutritional risk-based differences
sec.p: Only nine patients (6.7%) had good nutritional status as indicated by a total NSI score of 0–2 (Table 1). Patients were divided into two groups: those with a total NSI score of 6 or higher indicating people at higher nutritional risk and those with a total NSI score of 0–5 for people at lower nutritional risk.

Table 2 shows the nutritional risk-based differences in sample characteristics, and HRQoL at baseline and 6 months later. In bivariate analysis, patients with higher nutritional risk had a higher total comorbidity score than those with lower nutritional risk (p=0.038). There was a significant difference in the use of diuretics between patients with higher and lower nutritional risk (p=0.047). HRQoL as assessed by the LHFQ was lower in patients who had higher nutritional risk than in patients with lower nutritional risk at baseline and 6 months later (p<0.001, p=0.003, respectively). However, there were no significant differences in total LHFQ scores between at baseline and at 6 months in lower and higher nutritional risk group, respectively (t=1.881, p=0.065; t=0.331, p=0.741, respectively), and between the two groups (t=1.039, p=0.310). There were no nutritional risk-based differences for any other patient characteristics.

sec.title: Nutritional risk and HRQoL at baseline and at 6-month follow-up period
sec.p: Higher nutritional risk as indicated by an increase in total NSI score was independently associated with worse HRQoL in patients with HF (β=0.33, p<0.001), after adjusting for age, gender, aetiology of HF, BMI, NYHA class, LVEF, total comorbidity scores, use of beta-blockers and diuretics, and daily sodium intake (Table 3). Nutritional risk was an independent predictor (t=3.92, p<0.001) of worse HRQoL and explained 9% of the variance in worse HRQoL in the hierarchical multiple linear regression.

sec.p: At the 6-month follow-up period, a greater total NSI score indicating increased nutritional risk independently predicted worse HRQoL in patients with HF (β=0.35, p<0.001), after controlling for the previously described risk factors and daily sodium intake (Table 3). Nutritional risk was an independent predictor (t=4.02, p<0.001) of worse HRQoL and explained 10% of the variance in worse HRQoL in the hierarchical multiple linear regression.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This is the first prospective study to show that nutritional risk affects adverse health outcomes beyond sodium intake in patients with HF. This study demonstrated that HF patients with higher nutritional risk were independently at greater risk for having worse HRQoL after adjusting for other risk factors and daily sodium intake. These findings may give healthcare providers clinically relevant evidence essential for improving patient education. Clinicians caring for patients with HF need to be aware of the importance of nutrition self-care beyond daily sodium intake. In general, little additional information on dietary assessment, evaluation, or instruction for patients with HF has been included in the current guidelines, aside from the dietary sodium restriction.50–52 In addition, previous studies have demonstrated that patients with HF paid less attention to dietary advice and had some difficulty in understanding the importance of nutrition self-care for their quality of life.53,54 Accordingly, both the importance of nutrition self-care and the impact of nutritional risk on HRQoL should be emphasized in patient education. Early detection of patients at risk for malnutrition is recommended using the NSI checklist at patient bedsides to promote adequate nutritional intake.

In our study, approximately 60% of patients were at high nutritional risk and the average total NSI score was 6.64±3.34. The percentage of patients at high nutritional risk in our study is much higher than has been reported in the elderly population, among whom nutritional risk ranged from 5 to 44%.28,30,55 This result reinforces our knowledge that patients with HF are suffering from poor nutrition. Prior investigators13,15,56 reported that HF patients did not have adequate macronutrients to meet the required energy. Lemon et al.57 and Arcand et al.58 reported that the majority of patients with HF had deficiencies in micronutrients such as calcium, magnesium, and potassium. Only one randomized controlled trial showed the effect of a combination of micronutrient supplementation on quality of life in elderly patients with HF.20 Given these limited findings from previous studies, there is little evidence as to which of these nutrients is essential or in what doses they should be given in clinical implications. Thus, it does suggest the need for further investigation to provide standard dietary recommendations which may lead to improved health outcomes for patients with HF. In addition to standard guidelines, nursing interventions targeting adequate nutritional intake for patients with HF are required to be built on knowledge of individual eating habits and dietary patterns as well as utilization of their own resources.

In bivariate analyses, greater portion of patients in the group with higher nutritional risk were taking diuretics than in the group with lower nutritional risk (78.2% vs. 62.5%). Several studies have suggested a possible explanation for the relationship between diuretics and nutritional status of HF patients.16,59,60 Diuretics can alter the sense of taste, reduce appetite, and aggravate dryness of the mouth in combination with beta-blockers, which poses a risk of inadequate food intake. In addition, diuretics decrease absorption of nutrients resulting in muscle wasting or cardiac cachexia. Therefore, it is recommended that HF patients taking diuretics with beta-blockers should be closely watched and their nutritional status should be continuously monitored in clinical settings.

Previous investigators16,59,60 suggested that neurohormonal activation or increased proinflammatory cytokines could be linked to a biological mechanism connecting poor nutritional status and adverse health outcomes in patients with HF. Catapano and colleagues61 showed that HF patients with inadequate food intake had higher levels of proinflammatory cytokines. Additionally, prior researchers have reported that depressive symptoms are more prevalent in elderly people who have inadequate food intake,62–64 and depressive symptoms and micronutrient deficiency had a synergistic effect on cardiac event-free survival in patients with HF.65 These findings suggested that depressive symptoms play a role in the link between poor nutritional status and adverse health outcomes. Likewise, future studies are needed to determine the biological and psychological pathways which may explain how poor nutritional status affects adverse health outcomes.

HRQoL at 6 months from baseline seemed to be worse compared with that at baseline in our study, but there were no significant changes in HRQoL at 6 months from baseline in both lower and higher nutritional risk groups. Moreover, change of HRQoL within 6 months was no significant between two groups. Patients with HF in our study had a relatively high level of nutritional risk at baseline, which could explain why both groups experienced no significant change in HRQoL within 6 months. The mean level of nutritional risk score was 6.6, indicating high nutritional risk. The high level of nutritional risk in our sample likely resulted in the inability to detect a significant change of HRQoL over time within 6 months between the two groups.

This study has a number of limitations. Although a prospective study design was used in this study, caution should be taken in drawing certain causal relationships between nutritional risk and HRQoL. The 24-h urine collection for estimating daily sodium intake was conducted one time at baseline, reflecting daily sodium intake for that specified 24-h period only. Also, the NSI checklist used in this study is not a diagnostic instrument measuring actual nutrient intake. Thus, it is important to keep in mind that being at risk of malnutrition may be different from actually being malnourished. Findings from our study should be interpreted in light of these limitations. Further investigation is required to determine the impact of nutritional risk on survival or rehospitalization as clinician-centred health outcomes through randomized controlled trials and longitudinal prospective study designs.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Our data demonstrated that HF patients who are at higher risk of malnutrition had a worse HRQoL at baseline and 6 months later after controlling for daily sodium intake. This is the first study to determine the relationships between nutritional risk and HRQoL as a patient-centred health outcome in Korean patients with HF. In addition to close monitoring for nutritional risk at bedsides, patient education should focus on the link between nutrition self-care and HRQoL, as well as the importance of nutrition self-care. Further investigation is required to develop evidence-based nursing interventions for adequate nutrition intake and provide specific dietary guidelines which may lead to improved health outcomes for patients with HF.
